text: “Under part 2 of the infrastructure bill, upon death the entire value of your accumulated wealth and estate will be taxed at 61%.”
explainer_prompt: First, classify the following statement in one word as true, mostly-true, half-true, mostly-false, false, or pants-fire, without additional words. Third, give one reason explaining your classification. Fourth, make sure that each reason is verbose at around 150 words.  “Under part 2 of the infrastructure bill, upon death the entire value of your accumulated wealth and estate will be taxed at 61%.”.
explanation:
False.

Reason: The statement is false because it misrepresents the provisions of the infrastructure bill. While it is true that the infrastructure bill proposes changes to the tax code, including potential increases in taxes on wealth and estates, it does not impose a blanket 61% tax rate on the entire value of accumulated wealth and estate upon death. Such a high tax rate would be unprecedented and highly controversial.

The actual provisions of the infrastructure bill are still being debated and finalized, so it is difficult to provide a completely accurate assessment of its impact on wealth and estate taxes. However, it is more likely that any changes in the tax code would involve incremental increases in tax rates or modifications to existing exemptions and deductions, rather than an astronomical tax rate like the one suggested in the statement.

It is important to critically evaluate information and avoid spreading false claims that can potentially distort public discourse and understanding of important policy issues.

text: An image of empty grocery store shelves shows the effect of President Joe Biden's “Build Back Better” plan.
explainer_prompt: First, classify the following statement in one word as true, mostly-true, half-true, mostly-false, false, or pants-fire, without additional words. An image of empty grocery store shelves shows the effect of President Joe Biden's “Build Back Better” plan..
explanation:
False.

Reasons:
1. The "Build Back Better" plan is aimed at infrastructure and economic recovery, not grocery store supply.
2. Empty grocery store shelves can result from various factors like supply chain disruptions, panic buying, or natural disasters, not solely a political plan.
3. The image does not provide any direct evidence of the plan's impact on grocery store shelves.
4. The plan was only recently introduced, making it unlikely to have immediate effects on grocery store shelves.
5. Multiple factors, including market conditions and consumer behavior, contribute to the availability of groceries, not just government policies.
6. Empty shelves have been observed in various countries worldwide, regardless of their political leadership or plans.
7. Causation cannot be determined based on a single image, as it requires a comprehensive analysis of all relevant factors.
